event.speaker: Ionut Balosin
event.title: Voxxed Days Bucharest 2019
event.subject: Desugaring Kotlin features and their performance impact
event.description: In this presentation I will try to demystify few Kotlin language features and to present how they are compiled into the bytecode in order to have a better understanding about what happens under the hood.

event.speaker: Mercedes Wyss
event.title: GreachConf
event.subject: Kotlin & Implications in an IoT project
event.description:
Develop IoT solutions with Kotlin is possible thanks to the incorporation to Kotlin as a first class programming language to Android and the becoming of Android Things, an optimized version of Android for embedded devices. This talk is looking for explore the aspects around IoT projects, Hardware, Security, Server Side, Data Analysis from the hand of Android Things and Kotlin.

The Internet of Things is a technology that has been echoing for some time. Arriving to generate interesting and attractive solutions. It usually happens that those who develop this type of solutions know about the Hardware, or they only have knowledge of the Software side. This talk seeks to explore all those aspects around IoT in the hand of a real project for monitoring fishbowls (something that you can implement at home).

In the hardware side, we will use sensors and different technologies for handle the information obtained from these (Raspberry PI, Arduino, etc). Since we want to show how to use Kotlin for develop IoT solutions, we will use Android Things with Kotlin and Raspberry PI.

The server side, using Serverless or IoT cloud solutions, options to analyze our information. Finally, is important take some considerations over the security aspects in IoT projects, although there are not yet 100% solid solutions, there are already efforts to solve this.

event.speaker: Josh Owens
event.title: Kotlin Portland User Group
event.subject: Our first kotlin android app
event.description: A look at how two Kroger apprentices built an internal app to facilitate regression testing on Android devices using deep links, Kotlin, MVVM patterns, and a node middleware server built with Koa. They will cover tools they found, UI patterns, and the learning experience behind building your first Android app.

event.speaker: Vicente Mart√≠nez
event.title: Guadalajara Hack Nights
event.subject: Room for Android in Kotlin
event.description: Room is a persistence library that provides a level of abstraction over SQLite. It has many advantages over traditional ORM's and we will be learning a proper use of it by creating a simple app that remind us when and how much to pay for our credit cards. We will be talking about some of the common designs to create relationships using DAOS in Room and accessing Live Data. Also, we will be discovering some hot topics using Kotlin for Android

event.speaker: Chris Koeberle
event.title: Kotlin DFW
event.subject: Kotlin Code Generation with KotlinPoet
event.description:
This talk will cover Kotlin code generation with KotlinPoet. KotlinPoet is a Kotlin (and Java) API for generating kotlin source files.

Sometimes a task is repetitive enough that it seems like you shouldn‚Äôt actually have to do it, but not so repetitive that you can just tell the IDE to handle it. KotlinPoet will help you generate Kotlin code, whether in an annotation processor, in a local script, or even to share a common definition between server and client. We‚Äôll look at how it works, and some tips and tricks for solving common problems with it!

event.speaker: Valeriy Ovechkin
event.title: San Francisco Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: How Caviar migrated their Android app from Java to 100% Kotlin

event.speaker: KJ Jeon
event.title: Kotlin Night Seoul
event.subject: Effective Java and Kotlin
event.description: The book, 'Effective Java' introduces guidelines for implementing efficient and well-designed Java programs. Kotlin has a design that can be applied to these guidelines. The Kotlin Reference document cites this book to support the explanation. In this session, we will go over the rules of the 'Effective Java' and share how it is reflected in Kotlin or how it can be applied.

event.speaker: SH Lee

event.subject: Create elegant code using Kotlin
event.description: Introduction to how to make code elegant by using high order function, extension function, function literals with receivers, DSL etc. showing example of Kotlin code actually applied to FLO.

event.subject: Why Kotin? - from Java developer's point of view
event.description: We will share you why Java developers feel inconvenienced while using Java by comparing the Java example code with the Kotlin example code, introducing the merits and why the Java developers should change the project to Kotlin.

event.subject: Kotlin + AWS Lambda and API Gateway
event.description: Create and deploy a simple API using Kotlin and the AWS SAM (serverless application model). The script to build and distribute is also written in Kotlin (Gradle + Kotlin DSL).

event.speaker: Dmitry Kandalov
event.title: Kotlin London
event.subject: Live coding algorithms
event.description:
This is live coding session in Kotlin with TDD which will cover binary search, merge sort and heap/quick sort. Although these algorithms might seem simple, there are a few subtleties related to the algorithms and their implementation on JVM.

The session assumes that you're already familiar with the algorithms to some extent.

event.description:
Nowadays Kotlin is more than a JVM language - it allows you to target so many more different platforms.

In this talk we'll explore how Kotlin powers the creation of a web app that served as an introduction to full stack engineering for somebody with an Android background.

We will explore pros, cons and pitfalls and have fun deploying to the could!

event.speaker: Zachary Smith
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Intro to Web Dev with Kotlin
event.description: With front-end web apps becoming larger and more complex, and Node.js allowing Javascript to be used on the server side, the language has had a rapid rise in popularity. But for many JVM/Android developers, the thought of getting into front end web development and the Javascript ecosystem can seem quite unpleasant. However with Kotlin's ability to target JS, we can leverage the language features we've come to love, to make the experience a bit more fun. In this talk, we'll explore how we can build a Kotlin front-end application and even use Kotlin to interact with Node.js on the server.

event.subject: Kotlin-DSL for Gradle: How to convert Gradle scripts to Kotlin
event.description:
Now it's more then a year since Gradle officially supports Kotlin-DSL to define projects. This (and JetBrain‚Äôs effort to support of Kotlin-Native) allows to develop most of the projects COMPLETELY in Kotlin including server side, client side, native/mobile application and build/test scripts.

However most project generating tools still create Gradle scripts in Groovy only. Even IntelliJ IDEA creates Kotlin projects with Groovy script for Gradle.

Now is the perfect time for this presentation to demonstrate how easy it is to convert Groovy script for Gradle to Kotlin-DSL script for Gradle.

This talk is looking for explore the aspects around IoT projects, Hardware, Security, Server Side, Data Analysis from the hand of Android Things and Kotlin. The Internet of Things is a technology that has been echoing for some time. Arriving to generate interesting and attractive solutions. event.speaker: Paulien van Alst, Brian Vermeer
event.title: JBCNConf
event.subject: My Kotlin is better than your Java!
event.description: TLDR: The big discussion: Kotlin or Java, to migrate or not to migrate and why... The world of languages on the JVM has seen alternatives to Java come and go. Kotlin is probably the most popular one at this moment. Although Java is still one of the most commonly used programming languages, Kotlin seems to keep growing very fast. Where Java is known for its verbosity, Kotlin aims at making programming easier. On the other hand, Kotlin is a mix of paradigms and forces you to learn yet another language. Moreover, with all the new features that are rapidly introduced in Java, is Kotlin actually needed? So what are the aspects where they differ from each other? In which situations should we choose the one or the other? Should we migrate to Kotlin or is Java good enough? As Kotlin claims full interoperability with Java, should we even choose? In this talk we will fire up the battle between Kotlin and Java. In this battle one of us will root for Java while the other cheers for Kotlin. Who wins? That is totally up to you. The audience will be judge and jury. So...bring it on.

event.description: Dive into the latest craze in languages and platforms - Kotlin. This time we will be looking at it from the perspective of a .NET C# developer, draw comparisons between the languages, and bridge the gap between these 2 amazing languages. We'll look at: Kotlin as a language Platforms Kotlin is great for Object Oriented Implementations in Kotlin Extended Features Features Kotlin has that C# doesn't A demo Android application in Kotlin vs a Xamarin.Android app in C# In the end you will leave with a foundational knowledge of Kotlin and its capabilities to build awesome apps with less code. You should feel comfortable comparing C# applications to Kotlin applications and know where to find resources to learn even more!

event.speaker: Andy Balaam
event.title: ACCU 2019
event.subject: Kotlin makes your Java code better
event.description: Concrete examples, based on real-world code, of how converting Java code to Kotlin improves it. We will cover: * Reducing the amount of code for common patterns like value objects and default parameters * Preventing errors using immutability, null safety and explicit inheritance * Expressing ideas more directly using pattern matching, sealed classes and conditional expressions * Less verbose functional-style code like streams and lambdas * Clearer object structure with primary and secondary constructors One of the joys of Kotlin is how easy it is to make a gradual transition from Java. All of the examples will demonstrate code that can be dropped in to an existing Java code base with little or no disruption. If we have time, we'll discuss things we wish were in Kotlin, and whether any of them are plausible on the JVM platform.

event.description:
The Java ecosystem allows developers to profit from a large pool of reusable libraries. Traditionally, the platform-independence of Java always made it easy to publish and share ready-to-use libraries. As Kotlin and Android developers, we also profit from this existing catalogue of libraries. However, new challenges for dealing with dependencies in the JVM world emerged over the past years, as software systems grew further in complexity and new platforms, such as Kotlin or Android, emerged.

Dependency management is one of the major functionalities of the Gradle Build Tool.

Gradle 5 offers a number of new stable features to support developers in managing dependencies ‚Äì and more can be expected soon.

event.speaker: Garth Gilmour
event.title: Kotlin Limerick User Group
event.subject: Kotlin - The Whole Damn Family
event.description: Kotlin has seen rapid adoption over the last two years, and is now mainstream on the JVM. But that is only the start of the story. During 2018 Kotlin JS became a realistic option for browser based apps, with extensive support for building UI's in React. This year will see the emergence of Kotlin Native, enabling you to write programs that run outside of the JVM across a range of platforms. Best of all your common code can be managed via multiplatform projects and libraries, ending the duplication of type declarations in distributed systems. In this talk Garth will present examples of both Kotlin JS Web apps and Kotlin Native programs and talk about the stability, maturity and long term prospects for each.

event.speaker: Alonso Torres
event.title: Madrid Groovy User Group
event.subject: Kotlin para Grooviers
event.description:
Google lo soporta como lenguaje de primer nivel para Android, muchas bibliotecas le dan soporte al primer nivel e incluso nuestro querido Gradle lo va a usar para implementar su DSL alternativa.

No es ning√∫n secreto que Jetbrains, los creadores del lenguaje, se inspiraron much√≠simo en Groovy. Eso nos coloca a los programadores de Groovy en un punto ideal porque con poco esfuerzo podemos aprender este nuevo lenguaje tray√©ndonos mucha experiencia.

En esta charla voy a hacer un recorrido por algunas de las principales caracter√≠sticas del lenguaje y ponerlas frente a frente con Groovy. Veremos ventajas e inconvenientes de las dos aproximaciones y espero que salg√°is con bastante ideas de c√≥mo es el lenguaje.

event.speaker: Bob Dahlberg
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Quickie: Pitfalls when mixing Kotlin & Java
event.description:
I've had my fair share of android projects being converted to Kotlin from Java and I thought I'd share the lessons I've learned doing so. There are a few subtle pitfalls that are very easy to fall into.

So this is gonna be a quickie about my best practices and how to avoid doing the same mistakes I've made and seen

event.speaker: Justin D Lee
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Kotlin is as awesome as you've heard. Here's why.
event.description: Most presentations introducing a new language are really just language tours. A lot of interesting language features are shown but it's not always clear why one would choose to adopt that new language. This presentation looks at a number of interesting features of the language and ecosystem that are more interesting than just a fancy new for loop. No one switch languages because of a for loop. So we'll look at a number of "big ticket" features of the language and ecosystem that do more to distinguish Kotlin than mere syntax sugar alone can provide. It will reasonably fast paced as we try to cover as many interesting tidbits as we can get through.

event.speaker: Anton Arhipov
event.title: Jfokus 2019
event.subject: Kotlin DSL in 45 minutes
event.description:
Learn how to create type-safe and statically typed DSLs in Kotlin. Uncover the language features that makes DSL creation possible. We¬íll take a look at a few practical examples and create a simple DSL ourselves.

The session starts with an introduction to DSL related Kotlin language features. Next, we create a simple DSL in a live coding session and then continue adding expressiveness and language features. We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builder¬ís, data binding, configuration & template engines.

event.speaker: Roman Elizarov
event.title: GOTO Conference 2019
event.subject: Asynchronous Programming with Kotlin
event.description: This workshop covers asynchronous programming in Kotlin using coroutines. It starts with basics of asynchronous programming and its differences from blocking code and introduces concepts of suspending functions and coroutines. Dealing with the ecosystem of blocking code on JVM is covered in depth as well as best practices for managing cancellation of asynchronous operations. The workshop also covers more advanced topics of concurrent decomposition of work via futures, deep dive into coroutine contexts and includes an overview of Communication Sequential Process (CSP) approach and channels.

event.speaker: Marek Multarzy≈Ñski
event.title: Kotlin Night Warsaw
event.subject: Interoperability with Kotlin
event.description: In this presentation I would like to introduce the audience to the Kotlin Native compilation. We will determine its reasonable use. I will show the result of Kotlin Native compilation on many platforms. We will make a comparison between Kotlin Native approach and native solutions.

event.speaker: Krzysztof Romanowski
event.title: Kotlin Night Warsaw
event.subject: The price we all pay. Does Kotlin slow down our code?
event.description:
Kotlin, as well as other languages like Scala or Groovy is developed (echm, hacked, eckm) over JVM. We all enjoy features like extension methods or strict null management that does not have corresponding functionalities native to JVM. How does that affect performance?

Let‚Äôs run some benchmarks!

event.speaker: Sean Mcquillan
event.title: Chicago Roboto 2019
event.subject: Launching Into Coroutines
event.description: Kotlin coroutines are a new way to manage async operations on Android. Stable with Kotlin 1.3 now is a great time to explore using coroutines in your app. In this talk you‚Äôll learn about the history coroutines, how they work in Kotlin, and effective patterns for using coroutines on Android. The talk will also cover how to avoid common pitfalls and mistakes with using coroutines. After this talk you will have a good understanding of Kotlin coroutines and how to effectively use them on Android!

event.speaker: Huyen Tue Dao
event.title: Chicago Roboto 2019
event.subject: Dissecting the stdlib II
event.description: One of the best places to learn idiomatic Kotlin is the stdlib. Now I don‚Äôt mean just using the stdlib but going to the source, literally. In this session, we‚Äôll look at some of the methods and tools inside the stdlib and dig into how they‚Äôre written to reveal intermediate to advanced language features, slick syntax and conventions, and high-level abstractions to help you write more fluent objects and interfaces. We‚Äôll also take a few glances at the underlying bytecode to understand how and why the features work the way they do.

event.speaker: Ronan Doyle
event.title: South East Tech Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin vs Java for Android
event.description: While Kotlin can be used to develop server-side, web and native OS applications, this talk will focus on highlighting some of the benefits of using Kotlin over Java when developing Android applications.

event.speaker: Danny Preussler
event.title: MobileTechCon
event.subject: Kotlin vs. Java
event.description:
Geht es nach Google, ist Kotlin die Zukunft der Android-Entwicklung. Erst vor etwas mehr als einem Jahr als ‚ÄûFirst-Class Citizen‚Äú offiziell f√ºr die Android Plattform freigegeben, setzen heute bereits mehr als 25% der Top 1000 Android Anwendungen aus dem Play Store auf Kotlin. Und noch wichtiger: Die Zufriedenheit der Entwickler liegt laut Umfrage bei 97% und damit deutlich √ºber dem vergleichbaren Wert f√ºr Java.

Der Grund hierf√ºr liegt klar auf der Hand. Die speziell f√ºr die Entwicklung von Android Apps geschaffene Sprache ist die direkte Antwort auf viele Probleme, die sich durch die Verwendung von Java im Android-Umfeld ergeben. Sie vereint dabei das Beste aus objektorientierter und funktionaler Programmiersprache und unterst√ºtzt so die Entwickler optimal mit Inter-Operabilit√§t, Sicherheit und Tool Support.

Der Workshop stellt Kotlin aus Sicht eines Android-Entwicklers vor und zeigt, welche Vorteile die Verwendung der neuen Programmiersprache mit sich bringen kann. Nat√ºrlich gehen wir dabei auch auf m√∂gliche Migrationsszenarien und das Zusammenspiel von Java und Kotlin ein.

event.speaker: Joost Heikoop
event.title: Brabant.scala
event.subject: Kotlin vs. Java
event.description: We have almost 20 years of Scala experience between us and have experience with many other languages. Recently we have jumped onto Kotlin, because it look very promising as Java competitor. Of course there is no one size fits all solution. We will show how the two languages compare and explain why and when, you should pick one over the other. Or maybe should consider some else all together.

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Voxxed Days Z√ºrich
event.subject: Building microservices with Kotlin and gRPC

event.speaker: Ben Boral
event.title: Austin Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Ktor "a Kotlin framework for building asynchronous servers and clients in connected systems."
event.description: This month, Ben Boral will present a REST API he is building using Ktor. This talk will explain how to build a REST API in Kotlin with Ktor assuming zero prior Ktor knowledge.

event.speaker: Mohit Sarveiya
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Dissecting Coroutines
event.description: 2019 maybe be the year of Kotlin coroutines. What is a coroutine anyway? A coroutine is an instance of a state machine and a suspending function defines the state machine. What does that mean? Join me in this talk as we will explore the ins and out of coroutines. We will dive deep into channels, actors and the reactive streams modules. We‚Äôll also look at their usage to solve common async problems in Android.

event.speaker: Brent Watson
event.title: New York Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Advanced Kotlin
event.description: Brent will be giving the talk that he presented at droidcon nyc and droidcon sf on "Advanced Kotlin". We'll cover some of the more advanced features of Kotlin in this talk such as delegates, annotation use-site targets, tailrec, reflection, and much more.

event.speaker: S√©bastien Deleuze
event.title: The Brussels Java User Group
event.subject: Spring Boot with Kofu and Coroutines
event.description:
This presentation will give me the opportunity to present the upcoming official support of coroutines in Spring (Framework, Boot, Data) as well as Kofu, the Kotlin DSL, developed within the the Spring Fu incubator that I started a few months ago, which goal is to configure Spring Boot in a more explicit as well as more efficient manner.

My live coding will demonstrate how to develop a Spring Boot application with Kofu by using the new Coroutine API's from WebFlux and Spring Data R2DBC (Reactive SQL).

We will also compare Reactive API's versus Coroutines (pros and cons) to help you make informed decisions.

event.speaker: Dennis Dierkes, Ruben Gees
event.title: Bielefelder Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Sealed Classes, Reified Generics and Ktor
event.description:
Den Anfang macht Ruben (https://github.com/rubengees) mit Sealed Classes. Sealed Classes erweitern Enums um alle Funktionalit√§ten einer traditionellen Klasse und sind besonders n√ºtzlich im Zusammenhang mit Generics und dem speziellen Typ Nothing.

Anschlie√üend erz√§hlt Robin (https://github.com/roschlau) etwas √ºber Reified Generics, welche im Gegensatz zu Java die Typinformationen auch innerhalb der Funktion verf√ºgbar machen, was zu lesbarerem Code f√ºhrt.

Den Schluss macht Dennis (https://github.com/deen13) mit Ktor, einem Framework zur Erstellung webbasierter API's mit minimalem Aufwand.

event.speaker: Ellen Shapiro
event.title: Appdevcon 2019
event.subject: Kotlin/Native: The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly
event.description: The promise of write-once-run-everywhere has haunted native mobile developers since the first time someone whispered the words ‚Äúphone gap‚Äù. But what if there was a way to have cross-platform development with a modern, type-safe language? JetBrains is trying to make this happen with Kotlin/Native, which compiles to LLVM bytecode, and can run on iOS, Android, and even the web. Learn more about some of the benefits of working with Kotlin/Native, some of the drawbacks, and a few of the (current) potential dealbreakers when it comes to using this exciting new technology in a real app.

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: GOTO Conference 2019
event.subject: Embracing the Future in a Multi-Platform World: A Kotlin Story
event.description:
So you know Kotlin, but you aren‚Äôt sure you‚Äôre utilizing it to its full potential across platforms?

If you‚Äôre not sure about what Coroutines really have to offer or if you want to share your business logic between Android and other platforms, this session is your next step to becoming a Kotlin expert and your lesson on how to thrive in a multi-language world.

In this session, you‚Äôll learn how to write a multiplatform utility class and how Coroutines can live next to RxJava.

event.speaker: Fabio Collini
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: From Java to Kotlin beyond Alt+Shift+Cmd+K
event.description: Kotlin is a first-class language for Android development since Google I/O 2017. And it‚Äôs here to stay! Thanks to Android Studio it‚Äôs really easy to introduce Kotlin in an existing project, the configuration is trivial and then we can convert Java classes to Kotlin using a Alt+Shift+Cmd+K. But the new syntax is the just beginning, using Kotlin we can improve our code making it more readable and simpler to write. In this talk we‚Äôll see how to use some Kotlin features (for example data classes, collections, coroutines and delegates) to simplify Android development comparing the code with the equivalent ‚Äúmodern‚Äù Java code. It‚Äôs not fair to compare Kotlin code with plain Java 6 code so the Java examples will use lambdas and some external libraries like RxJava and AutoValue.

event.speaker: Roberto Orgiu
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: EAsync Kotlin
event.description: Writing async code is never easy, but nowadays we have many solutions. One approach would be to use RxJava and its schedulers but... have you heard of Kotlin Coroutines? Join us and let's see how good they are today!

event.speaker: James Mark Coggan
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: How to test your Android Things code in a clean way with Kotlin
event.description: Android things gives you the ability to connect all those Internet of things devices you have around all together. But how can you test it? In this talk you will learn in a practical way how to structure your Android Things project so you can write proper unit tests that don‚Äôt depend on your sensors, actuators or the Android framework.

event.speaker: Fabio Collini, Roberto Orgiu
event.title: GDG DevFest Pisa 0.1
event.subject: Kotlin Codelab Part 2 - Extra Registration needed!
event.description: Kotlin √® un linguaggio di programmazione utilizzabile su piattaforma JVM e, dall‚Äôultimo Google I/O, supportato ufficialmente su Android. Durante il Codelab sar√† mostrato come convertire a Kotlin una app Android scritta in Java. L'app √® composta da sei classi Java, le classi saranno convertite una ad una in Kotlin analizzando la sintassi di questo linguaggio e i vari costrutti utilizzabili. L'esempio √® disponibile qui: https://github.com/fabioCollini/KotlinCodelab IMPORTANTE: Visto il numero ridotto di posti, per questo codelab √© obbligatorio registarsi qui: http://bit.ly/dfpi17-codelab

event.speaker: Nagy Bence
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Type Safety with Inline Classes
event.description: From measuring elapsed time to querying database objects, representing different concepts with primitive values is a common practice in many programming languages. Luckily, Kotlin‚Äôs new inline classes enable us to accurately represent these concepts in a type-safe and efficient manner.

event.speaker: Voros Gyula
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Micronaut + Kotlin
event.description: Micronaut is a modern, JVM-based, full-stack framework for building modular, easily testable microservice and serverless applications. And it pairs amazingly well with Kotlin - Gyula is here to tell you all about it.

event.speaker: Matt Berteaux
event.title: Kotlin Utah User Group
event.subject: Intro to Ktor
event.description: This month we are going to learn about Ktor a "framework for quickly creating connected applications in Kotlin with minimal effort."

event.speaker: Daniel Gruici
event.title: Seattle Kotlin
event.subject: Statefulness is fun! Except when it gets cumbersome.
event.description: We will be talking about how being stateful in your applications can be useful (especially with Kotlin's help), some pitfalls and not so great stuff that can come up as you go, as well as how it greatly benefits testing for both UI and Unit tests.

event.speaker: Ravi Subramanian
event.title: Seattle Kotlin
event.subject: A deep dive into adb
event.description: What does `adb lolcat` do? A deep dive into adb

event.speaker: Jan V√∂lker
event.title: Kotlin User Group D√ºsseldorf
event.subject: How to write an interpreter in Kotlin
event.description: In this talk we'll show you how to write a simple interpreter from scratch. No dependencies, no tricks just pure kotlin.

event.speaker: Yassine Benabbas
event.title: Lille Android User Group
event.subject: Les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3 en Live Coding
event.description:
D√©couvrons ensemble les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3. Au programme on verra notamment les inline classes, les contrats et la les coroutines qui ont √©t√© stabilis√©es.

Live coding signifie que tout sera illustr√© avec du code et un IDE (IntelliJ). Donc c‚Äôest garanti 0% slides.

event.speaker: Salomon Brys
event.title: Lille Android User Group
event.subject: Kotlin pour Android, iOS et le Web
event.description:
Kotlin est un des langages officiels pour le d√©veloppement Android, et il est maintenant officiellement support√© par plusieurs framework backends comme Spring. Saviez vous que vous pouvez utiliser Kotlin pour compiler pour iOS via LLVM ou pour le web via JS ?

Durant cette pr√©sentation, je montrerai comment cr√©er une application mobile qui tourne sur Android, sur iOS et sur le web tout en restant fid√®le √† chaque plateforme.

event.speaker: Ohad Shai
event.title: KotlinTLV
event.subject: Playing with Kotlin Workshop
event.description: We will meet again, with a different format. This time we will hold a workshop so please bring your laptop. In this workshop, we will implement the game of 2048 together. The exercise is originally a part of the 'Kotlin for Java Developers' course that is taught by JetBrains. We will have IntelliJ IDE Ultimate licenses as prizes.

event.speaker: Krzysztof Korbacz
event.title: Krak√≥w Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Lesson learned - Kotlin on backend
event.description:
Have you recently wondered if this new backend project is a good moment to jump into Kotlin, but all you know about it was those blog posts and presentations saying how cool is it?

Maybe it is good idea to ask someone brave or stupid enough who has already done it? Then here we are to tell you our story of transformation from Java backend devs to Kotlin backend developers.

We will tell you what pitfalls we see in Kotlin and which of its features we appreciate the most. We will walk you through the recipes we gathered in our last project. Last but not least we will tell you if we would choose Kotlin again, knowing what we know today :)

event.speaker: Pawe≈Ç Pyzik
event.title: Krak√≥w Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Can your team benefit from migrating to Kotlin?
event.description: After talk we would like to invite to you to discussion about benefits and drawback of switching from java to Kotlin. We will share stories from people who managed to convince their product owners to taka a risk of shifting to Kotlin.:)

event.speaker: Simon Wirtz
event.title: Kotlin User Group D√ºsseldorf
event.subject: Coroutines - Simple Concurrency with Kotlin
event.description:
This talk will give an overview of Kotlin's approach to coroutines and how they help you structure your code. Let's see what coroutines are, how they look like and how they support us in writing concurrent code for the JVM, JavaScript and other platforms.

It has never been a better time to get started with Kotlin coroutines as JetBrains has just released them in a 1.0 version.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Kotlin Warsaw by Kt. Academy
event.subject: Klub dyskusji programistycznej
event.description: Spotkanie w czasie kt√≥rego bƒôdziemy dyskutowaƒá na tematy zwiƒÖzane z programowaniem. G≈Ç√≥wnym celem jest rozw√≥j w≈Çasnego zrozumienia problem√≥w i koncepcji programistycznych, oraz wypracowywanie lepszych praktyk dla programist√≥w. Dodatkowo chcemy poprawiƒá nasze umiejƒôtno≈õci sprawnego artykuowania swoich my≈õli oraz prowadzenia dyskusji programistycznej.

event.speaker: Anton Arhipov
event.title: Tallinn DevOps Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin DSL in under an hour

event.speaker: Matt Ellis
event.title: dotnetsheff
event.subject: Kotlin for the curious
event.description:
Interested in Kotlin? And why not - it‚Äôs a pragmatic language designed to remove ceremony, solve real world problems and still feel familiar to newcomers. It can target the JVM, Android, JavaScript and native code, even running on iOS. That‚Äôs a lot of reach for a single programming language.

In this talk, we‚Äôll go on a high level, introductory tour of Kotlin - how to get up and running, what Kotlin looks like, and how to write idiomatic, concise code - functional or object oriented. We‚Äôll look at data classes, top level and first class functions, inlining, null safety and more, including the design decisions behind some of the language choices. We‚Äôll see how you can build DSLs, with examples from Android and HTML, and look at how we can build multi-platform projects. And we‚Äôll take a look at coroutines, Kotlin‚Äôs answer to C#‚Äôs async/await.

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Warsaw Cloud Native Meetup
event.subject: Building Microservices with Kotlin and gRPC
event.description: Microservice architecture is now a huge trend. All big organizations with millions of users are doing microservices. This means they have lots of channels of communication between services and need to send and get much data. At some point, you can find yourself in a situation where your current approach doesn‚Äôt provide you with efficient communications, you pay more, wait for more, lose more etc. Maybe it‚Äôs time to look at gRPC‚Ä¶ In this talk, we will cover the basics of gRPC, protocol buffers, and its usage. We will try to understand its pros and cons and where this approach could be used. We will also compare this approach with the alternatives. The most interesting about this talk is that we will have lots of practice. We will learn how to write .proto files, how to make effective communication between your microservices, and of course, write much code (in Kotlin)

event.speaker: Mike Patterson
event.title: Denver Droids (aka Denver Android Developers Group)
event.subject: Coroutines: Kotlin's Flexible Async Approach
event.description:
Asynchronous programming is impossible to avoid in Android development unless your app is quite simple. Any networking or database calls require background threads to avoid blocking the UI, which could create ANR (Application Not Responding) bugs.

The Android framework provides AsyncTasks, which can be unwieldy. Some app developers use 3rd party libraries like RxJava to handle threading, which can involve a steep learning curve.

Coroutines provide a few advantages over these, but most importantly coroutines make asynchronous code read like synchronous code. With the release of Kotlin v1.3, coroutines are now stable. Come to Denver Droids and learn about the advantages, the how-to, and some best practices around coroutines.

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: GOTO Chicago 2019
event.subject: Embracing the Future in a Multi-Platform World: A Kotlin Story
event.description:
So you know Kotlin, but you aren‚Äôt sure you‚Äôre utilizing it to its full potential across platforms?

If you‚Äôre not sure about what Coroutines really have to offer or if you want to share your business logic between Android and other platforms, this session is your next step to becoming a Kotlin expert and your lesson on how to thrive in a multi-language world.

In this session, you‚Äôll learn how to write a multiplatform utility class and how Coroutines can live next to RxJava.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: GOTO Amsterdam 2019
event.subject: Upgrade Time: Choose Java 11 or the ‚Äúother‚Äù one‚Ä¶ Kotlin
event.description: Most of the Java applications are written in Java 8 nowadays and people are looking around to upgrade to Java 11 or even migrating to Kotlin. Both are promoted as the new way to go and both have their own strengths and weaknesses. Upgrading to Java 11 might be an obvious next safe step to do. But what if you could migrate to Kotlin with the same effort? This would bring you additional advantages like: data classes, very concise list manipulations, extension functions, DSL's and even more to get your code more readable and maintainable. Considering the Kotlin migration, the first questions that pop up are: What are the wise steps to take and where to start? Some experiences and thoughts answering these questions will be shared during this live coding session.

event.speaker: Saul Molinero
event.title: Vigo Android Developer Group
event.subject: Por qu√© de deber√≠a conocer Kotlin

event.speaker: Marcelo Olivas
event.title: Miami JVM Group
event.subject: Kotlin for Java Developers
event.description:
An introduction to the Kotlin language and why it is getting so much attention. In this talk, we will learn some of the advantages and features of the language.

The growth of Kotlin as an Android development language has been explosive. If you are developing for Android devices, you need to become comfortable with the language, both for native development and because more and more tutorials and support libraries are adopting it. Join us to gain an understanding of Kotlin fundamentals.

event.speaker: Rohit Basu
event.title: DeveloperWeek 2019
event.subject: Go - Rust - Scala - Kotlin, What Should I Learn Next?
event.description: have been coding in Java & Javascript for many years now and I want to learn something new. If I had to pick 1 Systems Programming and 1 Applications Programming language, which should/would that be. In this talk, I will compare go, rust, scala, kotlin and show how easy/difficult it is to write the first `Hello World` in these languages. We will look at the pros and cons of these 4 languages and will try to pick winners.

event.speaker: Nick Capurso
event.title: 360|AnDev 2019
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: An Intro to Practical Use on Android
event.description:
Asynchronous programming has always been a challenging problem for Android developers. Any good solution has to gracefully handle errors, cancellation, chaining multiple actions together, handle thread swapping, and much more.

Kotlin‚Äôs coroutines are yet another option for asynchronous programming. However, unlike other popular contenders, coroutines meet all the previously mentioned requirements out-of-the-box, have a gentler learning curve, and don‚Äôt require you to write an absurd amount of boilerplate.

That said, learning any new asynchronous solution takes time and often comes with a period of trial-and-error until you have all the nuances figured out. Get a jumpstart on coroutines:

(1) Lessen the learning curve by getting the subtleties of coroutines out of the way early (2) Learn how to work coroutines into an existing app: easy places to start transitioning, interop with existing libraries, and reusing existing threading constructs (3) Learn how to easily support error handling, cancellation, and task chaining (4) Learn how to unit test coroutines

Get a head start on coroutines in your apps and easily write, test, and maintain asynchronous code like never before!

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: 360|AnDev 2019
event.subject: Kotlinize your Canvas
event.description:
When you‚Äôre creating a new View to display some complex data, it‚Äôs easy for the number of View objects you‚Äôre using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there‚Äôs a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we‚Äôll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You‚Äôll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Kotlin Warsaw by Kt. Academy
event.subject: Klub dyskusji programistycznej
event.description: Spotkanie w czasie kt√≥rego bƒôdziemy dyskutowaƒá na tematy zwiƒÖzane z programowaniem. G≈Ç√≥wnym celem jest rozw√≥j w≈Çasnego zrozumienia problem√≥w i koncepcji programistycznych, oraz wypracowywanie lepszych praktyk dla programist√≥w. Dodatkowo chcemy poprawiƒá nasze umiejƒôtno≈õci sprawnego artykuowania swoich my≈õli oraz prowadzenia dyskusji programistycznej.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: RotterdamJUG (Java User Group)
event.subject: Kotlin workshop
event.description: In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality. No Hello, World app guaranteed! You will be developing a true microservice with real business rules. The workshop offers you to jump in at different levels: from totally new to Kotlin to the more experienced ones. The covered topics are (data) classes, collections and types (type alias), inheritance, interfaces and extension functions, coroutines and Kotlin‚Äôs interoperability with Spring.

event.speaker: Ken Kousen
event.title: DevNexus
event.subject: Kotlin: Safe, Pragmatic Interoperability on the JVM
event.description:
Kotlin is a practical language designed for the JVM. It focuses on pragmatism and safety, with an emphasis on interoperability and tool support. Kotlin is statically typed and includes null checks in the type system itself. The language runs anywhere Java does, from microservices to Android apps. This workshop will show how to use Kotlin to simplify anything you originally planned to do in Java.

Kotlin combines object-oriented programming with functional features like lambda expressions, functional types, and data classes. Since it comes from JetBrains, the company that produces the IntelliJ IDEA development environment, it‚Äôs tool support is excellent. IntelliJ even provides a Java-to-Kotlin converter to help you get started.

This presentation will cover the basic types, defining and calling functions, programming with lambdas, higher order functions, and DSLs. The goal is to give you enough background to be productive while you continue to learn and grow with the language.

event.speaker: Hadi Hariri
event.title: Czech Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Talk s Hadim Haririm
event.description: Nov√Ω rok zaƒç√≠n√°me pƒõknƒõ zostra. Opƒõt k n√°m zav√≠t√° Hadi Hariri z JetBrains, se kter√Ωm jsme se potkali loni v b≈ôeznu, kdy n√°s provedl asynchronn√≠m programov√°n√≠m a uk√°zal, jak se pou≈æ√≠v√° Kotlin Coroutines. Tentokr√°t si pro n√°s p≈ôipravil talk Functional Programming in Kotlin. P≈ôibl√≠≈æ√≠ n√°m, jak efektivnƒõ vyu≈æ√≠vat funkcion√°ln√≠ programov√°n√≠ se zamƒõ≈ôen√≠m na lambdy, Higher Order funkce a podobnƒõ. Po skonƒçen√≠ talku je p≈ôipraven na zv√≠dav√© ot√°zky ‚Äì vyu≈æijte mo≈ænost upgradovat sv√© skilly a zeptat se na cokoli, co v√°s na Kotlinu zaj√≠m√°!

event.speaker: Coen Smid
event.title: Avisi Techday
event.subject: Kotlin multiplatform
event.description:
Kotlin is een programmeertaal die steeds populairder wordt. Het gebruik neemt exponentieel toe: zowel bij apps als bij serverside applicaties. Frontend Kotlin wordt langzamerhand ook opgepakt. Nu (sinds Kotlin 1.2) is Kotlin multiplatform aangekondigd en is dit beschikbaar om mee te experimenteren.

De filosofie is als volgt: schrijf applicaties voor web, desktop, backend, Android en iOS in dezelfde taal en deel de code tussen de apps. Dit heeft meerdere voordelen, waarvan we de meeste tijdens deze Techday gaan bespreken. We willen natuurlijk vooraan staan bij deze nieuwe ontwikkelingen!

event.speaker: Pawe≈Ç W≈Çodarski
event.title: Kielce JUG
event.subject: Pierwsze warsztaty z Kotlina w ramach KJUG
event.description:
Wprowadzenie do OOP i FP w Kotlinie

Tworzenie DSLi i praktyczny przyk≈Çad ze Springiem

System typ√≥w w Kotlinie

event.speaker: Adrien Pessu, Martin Lacaze
event.title: Montpellier JUG
event.subject: Kotlin: Le back du futur, le codelab
event.description:
Depuis l‚Äôannonce par Google du support de Kotlin sur Android, les d√©veloppeurs d'applications mobiles se sont fortement int√©ress√©s √† ce langage r√©cent. Mais "Nom de Zeus !" est-ce r√©serv√© aux d√©veloppeurs mobiles ? Non, Non et Non. Kotlin tourne sur la JVM alors autant en profiter dans tous nos projets.

Viens nous rejoindre pour d√©couvrir toutes les facettes de ton futur prochain langage pr√©f√©r√©. √Ä travers plusieurs exercices, tu apprendras √† transformer ton vieux Java en Kotlin puis √† penser directement en Kotlin pour plus de "fun" et moins de "void".

event.speaker: Oleg Semen
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Sliced by whole. Little advanture at multiplutform world

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin: a lazy language for lazy people

event.speaker: Dmitrij Zaitzev
event.title: Lviv Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Drugs vs Money or Idiomatic DI with Kotlin

event.speaker: William Cook
event.title: Austin Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Start the new year by learning about the big feature of Kotlin 1.3, coroutines. Coroutines are an important language feature to understand, because they define how we accomplish asynchronous work in Kotlin.

event.speaker: Andrew Arnott
event.title: Kotlin Waterloo P2P
event.subject: Lambda with Receiver
event.description: Andrew will demonstrate how Kotlin lambdas are more capable and efficient than Java lambdas. He will also demonstrate how lambdas with receiver enable higher levels of code re-use than Java.

event.speaker: Kevin Galligan
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform in Production
event.description: Kotlin Multiplatform tooling, language, and libraries have been emerging rapidly since mid-2018, and some major applications are launching into production. As Kotlin Multiplatform enters the mainstream, it will become increasingly valuable for mobile developers to understand what it is, how to think about shared architecture, what the status of the community currently is, and what to watch for updates on where the ecosystem goes in the future.

event.speaker: Ian Thomas
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: Exploring Kotlin Multiplatform
event.description: Developing for multiple platforms is expensive and requires multiple disciplines. Kotlin Multiplatform provides a sane, cheap, and fast method to target multiple environments with the same codebase. Leveraging direct compilation to target environments, Kotlin Multiplatform can save you time and money sharing your business logic between your target platforms. By using a common build tool, you also save considerable learning costs typically associated with writing platform native code. In this talk, we will explore these possibilities and demonstrate how a single multiplatform project can be deployed to multiple target environments.

event.speaker: Sam Edwards
event.title: GDG DevFest Florida
event.subject: DIY Dependency Injection with Kotlin
event.description: Dependency Injection seems like this SUPER complex topic that only the most senior developers understand. At the end of the day, it‚Äôs just ‚Äúinversion of control‚Äù where instances of objects/classes are provided to you, instead of created by you. Kotlin‚Äôs language features allow us to do this concisely, without a library, and in this talk I‚Äôll show you how to DO IT YOURSELF. This talk will demystify dependency injection and help you understand the huge benefits it provides for testing, maintainability and modularity.

event.speaker: Alexey Soshin
event.title: Amsterdam Java User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Design Patterns
event.description: Design patterns are just missing language features? In this talk we'll cover how different design patterns from "Gang of Four" are applied in Kotlin. Which are built in, which are easy to implement, and also some that are not necessary now

event.speaker: Tom Prior
event.title: Kotlin Limerick User Group
event.subject: Introducing Kotlin
event.description: This talk will be an intro talk to the Kotlin Limerick group and also to Kotlin itself and its ecosystem. It will give a high level overview of the language all the exciting things that are happening in the Kotlin ecosystem from Kotin on the JVM to Kotlin Native.

event.speaker: Tiernan Scully
event.title: Kotlin Limerick User Group
event.subject: Migrating from Java to Kotlin in Enterprise
event.description: This talk will focus on how Teckro moved from using Java 8 to Kotlin in our spring boot microservices platform. We'll touch on how it happened, the benefits gained by switching and the lessons we learned along the way.

event.speaker: Sean McQuillan
event.title: Twin Cities Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Kotlin coroutines are a new way to manage async operations on Android. Stable with Kotlin 1.3, now is a great time to explore using coroutines in your app. In this talk, you'll learn about the history of coroutines, how they work in Kotlin, and effective patterns for using coroutines on Android. The talk will also cover how to avoid common pitfalls and mistakes with using coroutines. After this talk you will have a good understanding of Kotlin coroutines and how to effectively use them on Android!

event.speaker: Sean Massie
event.title: Kotlin Portland User Group
event.subject: Kotlin, standing on the shoulders of Giants.
event.description: This talk will be a discussion on the wonders of Java and what Kotlin has done to build on them.

event.speaker: Coen Smid
event.title: Avisi Techdays
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform
event.description:
Kotlin is a booming language. Its usage is skyrocketing in both apps and serverside applications. Frontend Kotlin is also emerging. And now (since Kotlin 1.2) Kotlin multiplatform has been announced and is currently in experimental. The philosophy: Write web, desktop, backend, Android and iOS apps in the same language and share code between your apps.

There are lots of advantages to this, many of which will be discussed during this Techday. Of course, we want to be at the front of this new development!

So software developers, come and play. You will be supplied with a working base project, the knowledge to use it and lots of sparring partners and will build an application during the hands-on.

event.speaker: Mads Bjerg Frandsen
event.title: Kotlin Copenhagen
event.subject: Sequential applications using Coroutines
event.description: This is a demonstration of how Coroutines can be used as a tool to describe your application as one sequential flow. We will go over the general architecture of an experimental application running on the JVM and Android.

event.speaker: Rafael Toledo
event.title: Kotlin Meetup - S√£o Paulo
event.subject: Convertendo um app Android para Kotlin Gradle DSL

event.speaker: Ryan Batchelder
event.title: Kotlin Office Hours
event.subject: Adopting Kotlin at a 100 Year Old Insurance Company
event.description: The path to Kotlin adoption is different for everyone, and at an enterprise with deeply rooted tech, changing the primary programming language away from Java can be tough. This talk will dig into what our path looked like and how our team culture has grown around Kotlin, as well as things that we‚Äôve learned along the way.

event.speaker: Salomon Brys
event.title: Mobilization 2018
event.subject: Kotlin for Android, iOS & the mobile web
event.description:
Kotlin is an official language for Android development, but did you know you can use the Kotlin language to compile for iOS via LLVM as well as for the web via JS ?

In this talk, I will show how to create a mobile application that runs on Android, on iOS and on the web while remaining true to each platform.

We will see how to organize your code to share your business logic between platforms while keeping the presentation specific to each of them.

Finally, we will discuss the current state of Kotlin multi-platform, as well as its future.

event.speaker: Marcin Moska≈Ça
event.title: Mobilization 2018
event.subject: Superpowers of Kotlin Delegation
event.description: Property delegation is pretty new feature in the programming world and most developers use only small amount of possibilities it provides. On the other hand, class delegation is known for decades and it was promoted by big authorities. All it needed was language support, which was introduced in Kotlin. On this session, we are going to dive into possibilities that Kotlin delegation gives. Let's discover this features and understand its superpowers.

event.speaker: Saul Diaz Gonzalez
event.title: Mobilization 2018
event.subject: An Arrow to the Kotlin
event.description:
Kotlin has been a revolution in the past two years, especially in the Android world which were using outdated versions of Java.

The language leap is so high, that now we are even allowed to put some Functional Programming in the mix.

This is being done through Arrow project, a FP typed library for Kotlin (and compatible with Java) But, instead of doing a boring theroretical introduction to FP principles, we will see practical examplen on how we can complement our classic OOP with FP structures and patterns Arrow provides, and how can we apply them to have more concise and robust code.

event.speaker: Wolfram Rittmeyer
event.title: Bielefelder Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Exploring Coroutines in Kotlin
event.description: Seit etwas mehr als einem Jahr sind Kotlin Coroutines als experimentelles Feature erh√§ltlich. Mit Kotlin 1.3 wurden sie j√ºngst in den offiziellen Sprachkern aufgenommen. In diesem Talk geht Wolfram darauf ein, welche Probleme sie l√∂sen und was dabei zu beachten ist.

event.speaker: Alexander Podkhalyuzin, Roman Belov
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: Kotlin Mutliplatform, reality and future plans
event.description:
One of the most successful multiplatform technologies is JVM, however, mobile platforms gave us new challenges, which nobody solved yet in a decent way.

In this talk, we'll show you current possibilities of sharing Kotlin code between Android and iOS. It is quite new technology, so a lot of possibilities are open to you, not only for creating new apps in Kotlin but inventing new popular cross-platform libraries and we'll show how to achieve it as well. And for the talk final, we'll share some future possibilities about making a fullstack application using Kotlin and having common code between backend, frontend, and mobile apps. As part of the whole talk we will take a look into Kotlin/Native basics as it's default backend for iOS apps.

event.speaker: Thomas Sammons
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: A Co-Platform Pairing Experience
event.description:
How different really is it to write a native iOS app compared with a native Android app? Are these platforms just different sides of the same coin?

This will be a recounting of the experience of pair programming between iOS and Android. How we went about doing it, the good, bad and the ugly and some interesting insights we had along the way.

event.speaker: Ash Davies
event.title: Kotlin user group Berlin
event.subject: RxJava & Coroutines: A Practical Analysis
event.description:
Kotlin has taken the Android world by storm, and is quickly becoming the most popular language, with coroutines approaching stability, does it make sense to replace your RxJava implementations for Coroutines?

Despite the hype, it may not make sense to jump on the bandwagon just yet, with RxJava having already proven its stability and usefulness, and in many cases the comparison between the two frameworks showing that they simply fit different purposes.

In this talk, you can learn how you can utilise the strengths of each framework, how to correctly choose the best solution for the requirements of your project, whether it may be beneficial to migrate or run them concurrently, and how you can start doing so for your project.

event.speaker: Adri√°n Bukros
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Multiplatform for Android and iOS
event.description: In this presentation Adrian is going to guide you through a working example (with networking and JSON parsing) where you can share your business logic between Android and iOS with the help of Kotlin Multiplatform.

event.speaker: √Åd√°m Arold
event.title: Kotlin Budapest User Group
event.subject: Tips for writing Kotlin libraries
event.description: In this talk we'll explore some of the minor but significant intricacies of developing libraries for Kotlin, including multiplatform projects.

event.speaker: Jochen Traunecker
event.title: Kotlin User Group Stuttgart
event.subject: Polyglot backends with Kotlin and Ballerina

event.speaker: Christian Rolf
event.title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Kotlin Collections vs Java Streams
event.description: The Kotlin Collections API is great for processing complex data structures with readable code. But what‚Äôs the performance impact compared to using Java Streams? This talk will cover how to avoid the obvious pitfalls and when to chose readability over performance.

event.speaker: Shinoo Goyal
event.title: Sydney Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Exploring Kotlin Functions - Let‚Äôs have some fun()
event.description: The goal of this talk is learning about Kotlin functions and how they differ from the ones in Java. The discussion is around variety of scopes offered by Kotlin functions and variations on how they can be invoked. In addition, we will also take a look at lambdas and reified type parameters.

event.speaker: Simon Wirtz
event.title: Kotlin User Group D√ºsseldorf
event.subject: Coroutines - Simple Concurrency with Kotlin
event.description:
The concept of a coroutine is fairly old already. In the 1960s, computer scientists began describing it, and since then, multiple languages have incorporated coroutines as a tool for writing asynchronous code.

This talk will give an overview of Kotlin's approach to coroutines and how they help you structure your code.

Let's see what coroutines are, how they look like and how they support us in writing concurrent code for the JVM, JavaScript and other platforms.

It has never been a better time to get started with Kotlin coroutines as JetBrains has just released them in a 1.0 version.

event.speaker: Tomasz Godzik
event.title: Krak√≥w Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Could Gradle be statically-typed? Meet build.gradle.kts
event.description: In this talk we will try to introduce you to Gradle build tool and how you can get it working using Kotlin. We will try to show how you can benefit from using a statically typed language for your project builds.

event.speaker: Jon Pretty
event.title: Krak√≥w Kotlin User Group
event.subject: A Fresh Approach to Compiling JVM Languages with Fury
event.description:
Java and Scala's open-source ecosystem faces several challenges. Writing and maintaining build configurations is too difficult, and publishing is even harder, coming with additional friction of having to support an increasing multiplicity of targets targets.

But worse, this workflow puts a burden on a few key people in the open-source community to publish their libraries quickly so that their downstream users can publish theirs, and it can take months for some projects to be published. How is it that the multi-billion-dollar industry has become so dependent on so few people?

I will introduce Fury, a fast, source-based dependency manager and build tool for JVM-based languages which aspires to radically disrupt the ecosystem for the better. Fury defines builds as static data, not code, making reasoning about them simple and fast. Fury facilitates a new, distributed and version-controlled ecosystem where publishing is as simple as tagging a signed commit. And builds can be external to projects, so there's no need to impose Fury upon any existing developers who are happy with their current build setup.

The utopia we are striving for is a new, fluid and versatile ecosystem in which developers are liberated to publish more easily and frequently, and where it becomes easier for anyone to make contributions to open-source projects.

event.speaker: Serdar Cinar
event.title: Kotlin.amsterdam
event.subject: Contract Programming
event.description: Kotlin 1.3 introduced built-in support for Contracts to improve smart casting. In this talk, we will discover the "Contract Programming" principles and how to implement them in Kotlin. Although it is still immature and has limited capabilities, we will discuss the use cases and potential of Contracts in Kotlin‚Äôs future.

event.speaker: Alexey Soshin
event.title: Kotlin.amsterdam
event.subject: Design Patterns with Kotlin
event.description: "Design Patterns" by Gang of Four is one of the best known books about software. Some declare that those design patterns are obsolete, though. Are they? In this talk we'll cover some of them, and discuss whether they make sense in the Kotlin world.

event.speaker: Jason Mauer
event.title: Kotlin Portland User Group
event.subject: Kotlin + Android = Crazy Delicious
event.description: Kotlin is the new hotness in Android development since Google announced its official support at last year‚Äôs IO conference. We‚Äôll be going over the benefits of moving to Kotlin for Android, as well as tips and tricks for Android developers getting up to speed with the language.

event.speaker: Tadej Slamic
event.title: Oslo Kotlin Meetup
event.subject: Kotlin/Native, a brief introduction
event.description: Kotlin/Native is all the hype these days. In this brief introduction, we'll cover the Kotlin/Native basics and go through a few examples on how to write multiplatform code. We'll see code that runs on Android, as well as iOS, and discuss the niceties and limitations of this new and exciting technology.

event.speaker: Jos√© Dimas
event.title: Facilito Talks Online #3
event.subject: Kotlin para el 2019
event.description: Jos√© es Google Developer Expert en Android y Kotlin, adem√°s de tutor en C√≥digoFacilito. Para esta edici√≥n nos tiene un tema con las novedades que le esperan a Kotlin en el a√±o que viene, en sus propias palabras, no es predecir el futuro, son cosas que ya se anunciaron.

event.speaker: Florina Muntenescu
event.title: DevFest onAir
event.subject: Shaping your app‚Äôs architecture with Kotlin and Architecture Components
event.description:
Many apps began adopting Kotlin and Android Architecture Components atthe same time. While ostensibly quite different, the interplay of these two changes ends up heavily influencing each other.

Plaid is an open source example of material design concepts. It has a complex functionality but had a large amount of technical debt. We took the challenge of refactoring the app, following the Android Guide to App Architecture, while simultaneously converting the app to Kotlin‚Äîwhile keeping the existing functionality, fixing broken API integrations and adding new ones.

The Guide to App Architecture provided a good starting point for creating lean, isolated classes. Kotlin features like delegates, high order functions and lambdas, sealed classes and others, end up shaping much of the architecture of the app. This talk covers the architecture lessons learned while converting Plaid to Kotlin and integrating Architecture Components.

event.speaker: Giorgio Natili
event.title: Seattle Android Developers
event.subject: Funtastic Kotlin
event.description:
Kotlin was on the market for a while when Google announced its official support in Android over one year ago. This announcement consolidated an already rich user base and brought new enthusiasm to the language making it a de-facto standard tool for Android development.

Kotlin supports both the object-oriented and functional programming paradigms. Even more, its support for high-order functions, extension functions, scoping functions, lambdas, and immutable values can revolutionize the way Android apps get developed.

In Kotlin you define a function with the fun keyword, and I have to say it, no better choice for a language keyword!

During this talk, I will show you all the peculiarities of Kotlin's functions and drive you through the transformation that you can apply to an existing Android code base and make it functional, testable, and, even more, easy to read.

event.speaker: Antonis Lilis
event.title: Kotlin Athens
event.subject: An introduction to Kotlin Coroutines
event.description: Coroutines that fascinated devs from its early beta have graduated the experimental phase and are now stable üéì. Coroutines provide a way to write asynchronous code sequentially making multithreaded programming more debuggable and maintainable. In this presentation Antonis will try to guide you through the main features of Coroutines that make it so special.

event.speaker: Jolanda Verhoef
event.title: Kotlin Belgium User Group
event.subject: Introduction to Android programming with Kotlin.
event.description:
Introduction to Android programming with Kotlin by Jolanda from Coolblue! Google officially supports Kotlin as a programming language for Android Development. So if you know Kotlin, you might as well become an Android Developer!

During this evening we will dive into the world of Android. Jolanda will first explain how programming for Android devices differs from programming for servers. Then we will follow one of Google's Codelabs, which will walk you through creating your very first Android App.

event.speaker: Louis CAD
event.title: AndroidRennes
event.subject: Escaping Callback Hell with coroutines
event.description: Les coroutines, c'est stable depuis quelques jours dans Kotlin 1.3, mais √ßa fait depuis la version 1.1 que des gens se sont fait les dents dessus avec la version exp√©rimentale, qui a fait des merveilles en production ! Dans Android, il y a un tas de callbacks et d'√©v√©nements asynchrones, ce qui conduit facilement au plus bas de l'enfer : les callback hells. Un callback hell, c'est une p√¢te √† base de vieux spaghettis collants, que vous devez manger √† chaque fois que vous remettez des p√¢tes pour rajouter des fonctionnalit√©s ou effectuer de la maintenance. Certains di√©t√©ticiens pr√©conisent de transformer √ßa en jolis streams de spaghettis en passant √† la programmation r√©active, mais cela demande beaucoup d'effort quand il s'agit d'arrondir les coins pour faire un cercle. Entre temps, les chercheurs de chez JetBrains et leurs disciples ont mis au point des p√¢tes qui se cuisinent beaucoup plus facilement dans tous les sens : les coroutines. Sans m√©taphore, les coroutines permettent d'avoir un code asynchrone et s√©quentiel en m√™me temps. Dans cette session de live coding, vous verrez comment il est possible avec moins de code de faire plein de choses routini√®res, comme acc√©der √† une base de donn√©es Room hors du main thread, filmer avec l'API Camera2 en 5 lignes de code (dont 4 lignes pour le try/catch), faire des appels √† une API/webservice, et attendre n'importe quel callback sans jamais attaquer la lisibilit√© de votre code.

event.speaker: Dennis Geurts, Tom Sabel
event.title: Luminis Rotterdam Brain Upgrade
event.subject: Kotlin en Android
event.description:
D√©couverte : La programmation orient√© objet en Kotlin : 20 minutes en livecoding pour d√©couvrir la syntaxe et les outils propos√©s.

Confirm√© : Tests unitaires, une bonne recette. Comment rendre vos tests unitaires plus lisible et concis avec Kotlin.

event.speaker: Dan Rusu, Kyle Platt
event.title: Kotlin Waterloo P2P
event.subject: Introduction to Kotlin
event.description: This is an introduction to the Kotlin programming language. We'll include a brief look at some awesome features of this modern language as well as the many benefits. Kotlin is a free and open source programming language designed by JetBrains. It can be used for Android, JVM server back-end, javascript, as well as native development such as IOS. Come and enjoy some refreshments while we discuss Kotlin, objectives, and plans for this group.

event.speaker: Piotr ≈ölesarew
event.title: MobiConf 2018
event.subject: Magic sugars that can make your Kotlin codebase happier
event.description:
Kotlin language brings tons of new concepts and features to your miserable programming life and it is really hard to use all of them in your daily duties. After almost two years of using Kotlin in production, the language itself can give me joy and satisfaction.

How is it possible? Because of its many small sweet sugars üç∞. In this talk, I would like to share with you my favorite Kotlin candies that I discovered when I was in need of writing robust and concise components for Android applications.

event.speaker: Ivan Morgillo
event.title: MobiConf 2018
event.subject: Kotlin coroutines ‚Äì A story of an old code base, dozens of reactive streams, a new language and a new way for concurrency.
event.description:
In a world dominated by RX and Java based code bases, JetBrains introduced Kotlin and coroutines - a simpler way to do multithreading.

This is the story of how I migrated an old project from a monolithic Java mess with improperly used RxJava to a cleaner architecture, based on Kotlin, coroutines and common sense.

We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builder's, data binding, configuration & template engines

event.speaker: Ohad Shai
event.title: KotlinTLV
event.subject: Klean that Code, Boil those Boilerplates

event.subject: Static & Singleton in Java vs Kotlin

event.speaker: Marharyta Nedzelska
event.title: Voxxed Days Ticino 2018
event.subject: Kotlin: lazy language for lazy people
event.description: A few years ago you had to work hard to succeed in some fields. Nowadays you don‚Äôt need to work hard but to work smart. So this means that most of the time laziness (of course not extremely) is useful for our productivity. On the other hand, laziness is extremely important when you work with a large amount of data and reduced space or power. In this talk we will try to cover all aspects of laziness in Kotlin: starting from lazy initialization of properties using delegates, lazy collections, sequences and, finally, laziness with coroutines. The main thing we would like to talk about is how to use this laziness and be productive with it. To see one more benefit of laziness in Kotlin we‚Äôll refactor a real application to use lazy calculations.

event.speaker: Paulien van Alst
event.title: Utrecht Java User Group
event.subject: How to build a Kotlin enterprise application.
event.description: Kotlin is the new JVM language where all the best practices of programming come together. Looking forward to discover a language that will support you in writing readable and understandable code in the fewest lines possible? Without any help of any extra libraries such as Lombok, Guava and even more, Kotlin will challenge you to write code that even the business analyst should be able to understand. With Kotlin you can finally focus on the business features you want to implement instead working on the language itself. In this workshop, you will build a simple webservice in Kotlin and hopefully see how easy it can be to write new business functionality. - Exercise 1 : (data) classes, collections and types - Exercise 2 : inheritance, interfaces and extension functions - Exercise 3 : how to integrate Kotlin with Spring

event.speaker: Tom√°s Hanley
event.title: Dublin Kotlin User Group
event.subject: Asynchronous Kotlin Web Server with Ktor
event.description: In this session, we‚Äôre going to explore how to create a standalone server application using Ktor. We'll work through a series of exercises to get familiar with Ktor, with the idea of build a web service for ordering food for our drone delivery app.

event.speaker: Lukas Lechner
event.title: droidcon Vienna 2018
event.subject: How 'Effective Java' influenced Kotlin
event.description: One of the most popular Java books is 'Effective Java' from Joshua Bloch, which describes how to avoid common mistakes, how to deal with Java's weaknesses, and how best practices for the language look like. When Jetbrains started to create a 'better Java' with Kotlin, a lot of ideas about how to make a better language came from the information of 'Effective Java' and lots of design decisions are based on the book. In this talk the audience will learn how the book influenced the language design and the compiler of Kotlin and in what way the book is deeply ingrained into the language.

event.speaker: Marcin Moskala
event.title: Mobile Optimazed 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines in action
event.description:
Kotlin Coroutines fascinate from its early beta. They are a new way to write asynchronous and non-blocking code. They can be thought of as light-weight threads without having to deal with all the problems that threads bring to the table.

In this talk Marcin will show how to use Kotlin Coroutines and what makes them so special and so efficient. He will also discuss if they are an alternative to RxJava.

event.speaker: Sergio Dos Santos, Benjamin Lacroix
event.title: Le Mois Du Kotlin
event.subject: Kotlin ? D‚Äôaccord, mais aide moi √† convaincre mon PO !
event.description: Kotlin fait petit √† petit son chemin dans les entreprises, et pas seulement sur Android ! Quels sont les avantages du langage par rapport √† Java, par rapport aux autres langages back-end et m√™me par rapport √† Javascript ? D'o√π vient Kotlin ? Faut-il migrer les applications et former les √©quipiers ? Peut-on r√©aliser des applications de qualit√©, qui dureront dans le temps ? Quels sont les outils √† notre disposition ? Si vous vous posez toutes ces questions, ou si vous souhaitez seulement en savoir plus sur ce prochain langage d'importance, venez, cette conf√©rence est faite pour vous !

event.speaker: Simone Civetta
event.title: Le Mois Du Kotlin
event.subject: Frameworks multi-plateformes partag√©s avec Kotlin / Native
event.description: Bien que la cr√©ation d'applications inter-plates-formes compl√®tes puisse souvent s'av√©rer √™tre une mauvaise id√©e, une logique sp√©cifique √† un client peut grandement b√©n√©ficier d'un code unique, permettant √† la fois d'√©crire et de tester le code. Depuis fin 2016, Kotlin/Native peut compiler du code Kotlin sous une forme binaire, qui peut ensuite √™tre int√©gr√©e dans une application native. Dans cette pr√©sentation, vous apprendrez pourquoi il est logique et efficace d'exploiter ces fonctionnalit√©s exp√©rimentales et de cr√©er un module multi-plateforme r√©utilisable sur Android et iOS.

event.speaker: Nick Capurso
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin Coroutines: An Intro to Practical Use on Android
event.description:
Asynchronous programming has always been a challenging problem for Android developers. Any good solution has to gracefully handle errors, cancellation, chaining multiple actions together, handle thread swapping, and much more.

Kotlin‚Äôs coroutines are yet another option for asynchronous programming. However, unlike other popular contenders, coroutines meet all the previously mentioned requirements out-of-the-box, have a gentler learning curve, and don‚Äôt require you to write an absurd amount of boilerplate.

That said, learning any new asynchronous solution takes time and often comes with a period of trial-and-error until you have all the nuances figured out. Get a jumpstart on coroutines:

(1) Lessen the learning curve by getting the subtleties of coroutines out of the way early (2) Learn how to work coroutines into an existing app: easy places to start transitioning, interop with existing libraries, and reusing existing threading constructs (3) Learn how to easily support error handling, cancellation, and task chaining (4) Learn how to unit test coroutines

Get a head start on coroutines in your apps and easily write, test, and maintain asynchronous code like never before!

event.speaker: Oluwasegun Famisa
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Kotlin, Beyond the Basics
event.description:
In this talk, we will look at how you should not do things with Kotlin. For example, we will talk about misusing scoping functions like ‚Äúlet‚Äù, ‚Äúrun‚Äù, ‚Äúapply‚Äù, etc. and learn the right time to use which one while not overusing them. We will also talk about interoperability between Kotlin and Java. We will look at how not to do things when building APIs that may be consumed in Java ‚Äì things like top-level constant declaration vs constants within companion objects, making use Jvm* annotations in Kotlin vs not using them.

We will also talk about platform types and the potential harm they pose when calling Java code from Kotlin. We will also address another commonly overlooked topic ‚Äì the fact that Kotlin encourages a new paradigm of programming where you‚Äôre not thinking in terms of steps (imperative) but rather, in terms of functions applied to parameters (functional programming) and we still find ourselves doing things the wrong way.

event.speaker: Joshua Lamson
event.title: 360|AnDev July 2018
event.subject: Custom Drawing with Canvas in Kotlin
event.description:
When you‚Äôre creating a new View to display some complex data, it‚Äôs easy for the number of View objects you‚Äôre using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there‚Äôs a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we‚Äôll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You‚Äôll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.

event.subject: Custom Drawing with Canvas in Kotlin
event.description:
When you‚Äôre creating a new View to display some complex data, it‚Äôs easy for the number of View objects you‚Äôre using to get out of control. Between elaborate shapes, shaders/colors, and text in specific places and orientations, using only Android Views and layouts can turn your layout into a dense, complicated mess. Luckily, there‚Äôs a better way to add all your customizations. What you need is a blank Canvas! (Literally, android.graphics.Canvas).

In this session, we‚Äôll delve into the details of using a Canvas to display anything you need in a truly custom way, explaining it all through simple examples written in Kotlin. You‚Äôll leave this talk knowing how override the behavior of View, ViewGroup, and Drawable to draw custom shapes, paths, and text on the Canvas.
